sub_topic: Finding the antiderivative of a function
message_1: Given the function f(x) = 2x^3 - 5x^2 + 3x - 1, find its antiderivative F(x).
message_2:
To find the antiderivative F(x) of the function f(x) = 2x^3 - 5x^2 + 3x - 1, we will integrate the function with respect to x. 

Integration involves finding the antiderivative of each term in the function and adding a constant C, since the derivative of a constant is zero.

The antiderivative of x^n is (x^(n+1))/(n+1), so we apply this rule to each term:

∫(2x^3) dx = (2/4)x^4 = (1/2)x^4
∫(-5x^2) dx = (-5/3)x^3
∫(3x) dx = (3/2)x^2
∫(-1) dx = -x

Now, we add all the antiderivatives together and include the constant C:

F(x) = (1/2)x^4 - (5/3)x^3 + (3/2)x^2 - x + C
